conclusion: Consider the forces acting on the small ball to find the electric field strength.
The forces acting on the ball are the gravitational force and the electric force.
The ball is suspended by an insulating string at an angle θ with the vertical.
Gravitational force acts in the downward direction.
The tension in the string is equal to the weight of the ball, mg.
Electric force acts in the direction of the electric field.
Electric force must be equal in magnitude and opposite in direction to the gravitational force, -qE.
The ball is at rest, so the net force acting on it must be zero.
Net force is the sum of gravitational force and electric force, mg = -qE.
Rearrange the equation to solve for E: E = mg/q.
Substitute known values: m = 1 kg, g = 9.8 m/s², q = 1 C.
The electric field strength of the uniform electric field is 9.8 N/C.
